trans-unit.source: Register for Google authentication | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Register for Google authentication | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to register your apps to use Google to authenticate with Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to register your apps to use Google to authenticate with Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Register your apps for Google login with Mobile Services
trans-unit.target: Register your apps for Google login with Mobile Services

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to register your apps to be able to use Google to authenticate with Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to register your apps to be able to use Google to authenticate with Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This tutorial is about [Azure Mobile Services](http://azure.microsoft.com/services/mobile-services/), a solution to help you build scalable mobile applications for any platform.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This tutorial is about [Azure Mobile Services](http://azure.microsoft.com/services/mobile-services/), a solution to help you build scalable mobile applications for any platform.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services makes it easy to sync data, authenticate users, and send push notifications.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services makes it easy to sync data, authenticate users, and send push notifications.

trans-unit.source: This page supports the [Get Started with Authentication](mobile-services-ios-get-started-users.md) tutorial, which shows how to sign in users to your app.
trans-unit.target: This page supports the [Get Started with Authentication](mobile-services-ios-get-started-users.md) tutorial, which shows how to sign in users to your app.

trans-unit.source: If this is your first experience with Mobile Services, please complete the tutorial [Get Started with Mobile Services](mobile-services-ios-get-started.md).
trans-unit.target: If this is your first experience with Mobile Services, please complete the tutorial [Get Started with Mobile Services](mobile-services-ios-get-started.md).

trans-unit.source: To complete the procedure in this topic, you must have a Google account that has a verified email address.
trans-unit.target: To complete the procedure in this topic, you must have a Google account that has a verified email address.

trans-unit.source: To create a new Google account, go to accounts.google.com.
trans-unit.target: To create a new Google account, go to accounts.google.com.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the [Google apis](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=268303) website, sign-in with your Google account credentials, click **Create Project**, provide a **Project name**, then click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the [Google apis](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=268303) website, sign-in with your Google account credentials, click **Create Project**, provide a **Project name**, then click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: In the left navigation bar, click **API & Auth**, then under **Social APIs** click **Google+ API** > **Enable API**.
trans-unit.target: In the left navigation bar, click **API & Auth**, then under **Social APIs** click **Google+ API** > **Enable API**.

trans-unit.source: Click **API & Auth** > **Credentials** > **OAuth consent screen**, then select your **Email address**, enter a **Product Name**, and click **Save**.
trans-unit.target: Click **API & Auth** > **Credentials** > **OAuth consent screen**, then select your **Email address**, enter a **Product Name**, and click **Save**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Credentials** tab, click **Add credentials** > **OAuth 2.0 client ID**, then select **Web application**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Credentials** tab, click **Add credentials** > **OAuth 2.0 client ID**, then select **Web application**.

trans-unit.source: Type your mobile service URL in **Authorized JavaScript Origins**, replace the generated URL in **Authorized Redirect URI** with the URL of your mobile service appended with the path `/login/google`, and then click **Create client ID**.
trans-unit.target: Type your mobile service URL in **Authorized JavaScript Origins**, replace the generated URL in **Authorized Redirect URI** with the URL of your mobile service appended with the path `/login/google`, and then click **Create client ID**.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] For a .NET backend mobile service published to Azure by using Visual Studio, the redirect URL is the URL of your mobile service appended with the path _signin-google_ your mobile service as a .NET service, such as `https://todolist.azure-mobile.net/signin-google`.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] For a .NET backend mobile service published to Azure by using Visual Studio, the redirect URL is the URL of your mobile service appended with the path _signin-google_ your mobile service as a .NET service, such as `https://todolist.azure-mobile.net/signin-google`.

trans-unit.source: On the next screen, make a note of the values of the client ID and client secret.
trans-unit.target: On the next screen, make a note of the values of the client ID and client secret.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] The client secret is an important security credential.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] The client secret is an important security credential.

trans-unit.source: Do not share this secret with anyone or distribute it within a client application.
trans-unit.target: Do not share this secret with anyone or distribute it within a client application.

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to configure your mobile service to use Google sign-in for authentication in your app.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to configure your mobile service to use Google sign-in for authentication in your app.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
